titleStmt.title: Writs and receipts for 8 Henry V

editionStmt.edition: TEI/XML English translation of writs and receipts for 8 Henry V

publicationStmt.publisher: Trinity College Dublin, The University of Dublin

address.name: Beyond 2022: Ireland's Virtual Record Treasury
address.addrLine: Trinty College Dublin, the University of Dublin

seriesStmt.title: Irish Exchequer Accounts (The National Archives, E 101).

msIdentifier.msName: Writs and receipts. 8 Hen V. 1 file.

projectDesc.p: Created as part of the Medieval Gold Seam of the 'Beyond 2022: Ireland's Virtual Record Treasury' Research Project, Phase 2 (2019–22)

editorialDecl.p: The guiding principle is to make this edition of the accounts of the medieval Irish Exchequer (and other medieval records populating Beyond 2022 Virtual Record Treasury) as intelligible as possible to as wide an audience as possible. To that end, due to their generally brief, formulaic nature the records are more or less directly translated into modern English without losing the literal, technical sense of the original language, which is almost exclusively Latin.

body.p: Acquittance of John White, attorney of the lord king in the Irish exchequer, that he received in the Common Bench from Hugh Burgh, treasurer and the chamberlain of the aforesaid exchequer 50s of his annual fee of 100s. At the exchequer, 25 July [1420] 8 Henry V.

Henry V to the treasurer and chamberlains of the Irish exchequer. With reference to letter patent 18 March [1412] 1 Henry V appointing John White as king’s attorney in the exchequer and Common Bench, order to grant him 50s of the arrears of his fee from 18 March [1414] 1 Henry V, on which day he was appointed by assent of Thomas, archbishop of Dublin, then justiciar of Ireland, during good behaviour taking a fee of 100s annually until 24 July [1420] last. Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant of Ireland. Dublin 25 July [1420] 8 Henry V. For the bibliography, in CIRCLE here https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/Close/8-henry-v/9

Henry V to the treasurer and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer. John Passevaunt. https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/close/8-henry-v/12. This writ is heavily faded and needs to be looked at under UV light.

Acquittance of Henry Strangeways, chief chamberlain of the exchequer in Ireland, that he received from Hugh Burgh, knight, treasurer and the chamberlains of the exchequer 66s 8d of his annual fee of 10 marks. At the exchequer 15 July [1420] 8 Henry V.

Henry V to the treasurer of Ireland or his deputy and the chamberlains of the exchequer. Confirming grants of 26 January [1405] 6 Henry IV under the great seal of Ireland, letters patent 2 March [1410] 11 Henry IV under the great seal of England, and grant 29 May [1414] 2 Henry V, to Henry Strangeways of the office of chief chamberlain of the Irish exchequer for life, at a fee of 10 marks and robes annually received at the exchequer, as Robert Sutton had had as chief chamberlain.
Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant, Dublin 13 July [1420] 8 Henry V.https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/patent/2-henry-v/116
Acquittance of Hugh Burgh, knight, treasurer of Ireland that he had received £36 6s 10½ d completing his fee of 3s 4d per day. At the exchequer 16 July [1420] 8 Henry V.

Henry V to treasurer and chamberlains of the Irish exchequer. Hugh Burgh, treasurer of Ireland, has pleaded that he was appointed to that office by letters patent, and granted the customary fee, and that some treasurers of Ireland before this time received £40 yearly and 5s daily, others received £40 yearly and and 6s 8d daily. He seeks a competent reward beyond the customary fee from 18 Sept. [1414] 2 Henry V, when he was sworn into office, and thereafter for as long as he held the office. Of the king's special grace and by assent of John Talbot of Halomshire, former lieutenant of Ireland, and the king’'s council of the same land, the king granted Hugh 3s 4d a day from the said 18 September [1414] and thereafter for as long as he held that office.

Wishing to be informed as to the arrears of Hugh, the king ordered the treasurer and chamberlains to search the rolls, records, and memoranda of the exchequer, returning their findings in chancery under the seal of the exchequer. They returned that his arrears from 18 Sept. [1414] until 9 July [1420] last amount to £74 18s 7 ½d. They are to pay Hugh that sum, receiving from Hugh letters of acquittance. Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant of Ireland at Dublin 10 July [1420] 8 Henry V. https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/patent/2-henry-v/116 and https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/Close/8-henry-v/5

Acquittance from John Batman chirographer and keeper of the records of the Common Bench of Ireland, receiving from Hugh Burgh treasurer and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer in Ireland 25s of his fee of 100s yearly. At the exchequer, 4 July [1420] 8 Henry V.

Henry V to the treasurer or his deputy and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer. Henry IV, father of the present king, granted to John Bateman, during good behavior, the office of chirographer and keeper of the records of the Common Bench at the usual fee of 100s yearly. By letters patent of England 13 June [1413] 1 Henry V confirmed John Bateman in that office.

Wishing to be informed as to the arrears of his 100s fee from 12 November [1413] 1 Henry V, when John was sworn into office as John fitz Adam, former chief justice of the Common Bench of Ireland, has testified before the king in the Irish chancery, the king ordered the treasurer and chamberlains to search the rolls and memoranda in the exchequer, returning their findings in chancery under the exchequer seal. They returned that his arrears from 12 Nov. [1413] until 20 June [1420] last amount to 25s. He orders them to pay him those 25s; and, moreover, they are to pay him those 100s per annum henceforth annually, receiving from him letters of acquittance. Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant of Ireland Dublin 24 July [1420] 8 Henry V. https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/Close/8-henry-v/8

Acquittance of John Blakeney, chief justice of the Common Bench in Ireland, that he had received from Hugh Burgh, knight, treasurer and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer £8 4¾d of his fee of £40 yearly. At the exchequer 20 July [1420] 8 Henry V. Related to https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/patent/8-henry-v/24

Acquittance of Stephen Bray, chief justice of the King’s Bench in Ireland, that he had received from Hugh Burgh, knight, treasurer and the chamberlains of the Irish Exchequer £26 13s 4d of his fee of £40 yearly and 40d daily. At the exchequer, 23 July [1420] 8 Henry V.

Acquittance of Thomas Brown [Broune] clerk of the crown in the Irish chancery that he had received from Hugh Burgh, knight, treasurer, and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer 66s 8d of his fee of 10 marks yearly. At the exchequer, 3 July [1420] 8 Henry V.

Henry V to the treasurer or his deputy and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer. On account of his fidelity and circumspection, having granted to John Blakeney on 26 April [1420] last the office of chief justice of the Common Bench in Ireland, to hold during good behaviour by letter patent, receiving the customary fee and wages. Wishing to be informed of the arrears of his fees from 26 April last to 9 July last, the king ordered the treasurer and chamberlains of the exchequer to search the rolls and records. They returned that the arrears of John’s fee of £40 annually, which other chief justices of the Common Bench were accustomed to receive before this time, from 26 April until 9 July, that is 75 days inclusive, are £8 4s ¾d. The king orders them to pay John the said £8 4s ¾d and the £40 annually of his fee year by year and term by term. They are also to receive from John letters of acquittance. Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant of Ireland at Dublin, 10 July [1420] 8 Henry V. https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/close/8-henry-v/4

Henry V to the treasurer of Ireland or his deputy, and the chamberlains of the Irish Exchequer. Having appointed on 28 September [1413] 1 Henry V by letter patent Stephen Bray as chief justice of King’s Bench in Ireland, to have in that office the fees that the same Stephen had in the same office in the time of Henry IV, [the king’s] father. Wishing to know Stephen’s arrears from 28 September [1413] to 12 July [1420] last, the king ordered the treasurer and chamberlains to search the records of the exchequer and to return their findings in chancery. They returned that of Stephen’s fee of £40 annually and 40d daily, the arrears from 28 September until 28 June last are £487 12s 2d. The king orders them to pay the £487 12s 2d and to pay Stephen’s wages year by year, term by term, receiving from the said Stephen letters of acquittance. Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant of Ireland, at Dublin 13 July [1420] 8 Henry V. https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/close/8-henry-v/6

Henry V to the treasurer of Ireland or his deputy, and the chamberlains of the Irish exchequer. When his father, Henry IV, 12 January [1402] 3 Henry IV by letters patent and he has confirmed on 31 January [1414] 1 Henry V by his letters patent, grant to Thomas Broun the office of clerk of the crown in the chancery of Ireland for the term of his life, receiving 10 marks annually at the exchequer in equal portions at Michaelmas and Easter . Wishing to know the arrears of the said Thomas of his fee of ten marks from the aforesaid 12 January until 2 May last, has ordered the treasurer and chamberlains to search the records of the exchequer and to return their findings in chancery. They returned that the arrears of Thomas’ fee of 10 marks annually until 20 March [1413] 14 Henry IV were £25 12s 8d and similarly the arrears of the said Thomas of his fee January to 2 May last, viz six and a quarter years complete, £29 18s 8d . The king orders them to pay Thomas £25 12s 8d and £29 18s 8d, and to pay his fee year by year, term by term during the time of the life of the said Thomas, receiving acquittance from him. Endorsed by James Butler, earl of Ormond, lieutenant of Ireland, at Dublin 8 July . https://chancery.tcd.ie/document/close/8-henry-v/2

Acquittance of John Passegent, clerk, keeper or clerk of the hanaper of chancery in Ireland, that he had received from Hugh Burgh, and the chamberlains of the exchequer 50s of his fee. At the exchequer, [1420] 8 Henry V

Acquittance of Sir Laurence Mer]bury, chancellor of Ireland that he has received from Hugh Burgh, treasurer and the chamberlains of the exchequer ??? in part satisfaction of the arrears of his fee. At the exchequer 11 July [1420] 8 Henry V.
